title: 111_hr2424
content: The Act is titled the "Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009". It includes findings related to the Act. The Congress found that in August 2007, liquidity dried up in credit and securities markets, initially affecting financial firms with interests in mortgage-backed securities. This lack of credit access spread globally, leading to the Federal Reserve establishing a target range of 0 to 0.25 percent in response to the financial crisis. The Federal Reserve responded to the financial crisis by acknowledging its severity and exercising its authority to address "unusual and exigent circumstances" multiple times since 2008. This action was last taken in 1934 before the current crisis. The Board extended assistance to nonmember institutions in efforts to provide liquidity and stability to the financial markets. The Federal Reserve responded to the financial crisis by providing assistance to nonmember institutions and purchasing debt obligations from government-sponsored enterprises. Additionally, joint programs were established with the Department of the Treasury to aid financial markets, including guaranteeing assets of Citigroup and Bank of America. Chairman Ben Bernanke affirmed his commitment to transparency during this time. Chairman Ben Bernanke reaffirmed his commitment to transparency during his testimony to the Committee on Financial Services of the House of Representatives, stating that the Federal Reserve is dedicated to keeping Congress and the public informed about its lending programs and balance sheet. SEC. 3. REVIEWS OF SPECIAL FEDERAL RESERVE CREDIT FACILITIES. Section 714 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to allow the Comptroller General to conduct reviews of credit facilities established by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System or any Federal reserve bank. This includes onsite examinations when deemed necessary. The Federal Reserve Act allows the Board to act as the lender of last resort and provide temporary assistance to private institutions through various credit facilities. These facilities include the Money Market Investor Funding Facility, Asset-Backed Commercial Paper Money Market Mutual Fund Liquidity Facility, Term Asset-Backed Securities Loan Facility, Term Auction Facility, Primary Dealer Credit Facility, and Commercial Paper Funding Facility. The Federal Reserve Act authorizes the Board to provide temporary assistance to private institutions through various credit facilities, including the Commercial Paper Funding Facility, Term Securities Lending Facility, Maiden Lane LLC, Revolving Credit Facility, and Mortgage Backed Securities Purchase Program. The Federal Reserve Act allows the Board to offer temporary aid to private institutions through credit facilities like the Commercial Paper Funding Facility and Term Securities Lending Facility. Paragraph (1) of the Act will expire after 5 years from enactment, with a required report by the Comptroller General to Congress within 90 days of each review conducted under paragraph (1). The report must detail findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislative or administrative action. Access to records is addressed in Section 4. Access to records for agencies and credit facilities is amended to allow the Comptroller General access to officers, employees, contractors, and representatives at any reasonable time. The Comptroller General can make and retain copies of records as deemed appropriate. Unauthorized access to records is also addressed in the amendment. The amendment allows the Comptroller General access to records and credit facilities, enabling the making and retention of copies as necessary.
